hints_html:
Try drawing a picture first (in the solution, we will set the origin to be the top most point).

Use similar triangles to find the width y of a small rectangular prism at height \(x_{i}^{*}\).

The following formulas will probably be useful

Volume = length x width x height

Mass = volume x density

Force = acceleration x mass = gravity x mass = 9.8 x mass

Work = force x displacement
hints_latex:
Try drawing a picture first (in the solution, we will set the origin to
be the top most point).

Use similar triangles to find the width \emph{y} of a small rectangular
prism at height $x_{i}^{*}$.
hints_raw:
Try drawing a picture first (in the solution, we will set the origin to be the top most point).
Use similar triangles to find the width ''y'' of a small rectangular prism at height <math> x_{i}^{*} </math>.
The following formulas will probably be useful

 Volume = length x width x height

 Mass = volume x density

 Force = acceleration x mass = gravity x mass = 9.8 x mass

 Work = force x displacement
question: 7 (b)
sols_html:
A picture is included at the bottom of the page. Let \(x_{i}^{*}\) be a sample point.

First, we use similar triangles as in the diagram to see that

\(\displaystyle \frac{1}{2} = \frac{y}{2-x_{i}^{*}}\)

Isolating yields that

\(\displaystyle y = 1 - \frac{x_{i}^{*}}{2}\)

Now we use hint 3 and write down the necessary formulas. For volume of the ith piece, we have

\(V_{i} = y\Delta x \cdot 10 = 10( 1 - \frac{x_{i}^{*}}{2})\Delta x = (10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x\)

For the mass of the ith piece, where \(density = \rho =1000\), we have

\(m_{i} = V\cdot \rho = (10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x (1000) = 1000(10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x\)

For the force, where \(g = 9.8\), we have

\(F_{i} = m_{i}a = 9.8(1000(10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x) = 9800(10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x\)

For the work on the ith piece, we have

\(W_{i} = F_{i} \cdot d = 9800(10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x(x_{i}^{*}) = 9800x_{i}^{*}(10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x\)

and so the total work done is

\(W = \lim_{n \to \infty}\sum_{i=1}^{n}W_{i} = \int_{0}^{2}9800x(10-5x)\,dx\)

completing the question.
sols_latex:
A picture is included at the bottom of the page. Let $x_{i}^{*}$ be a
sample point.

First, we use similar triangles as in the diagram to see that

$\displaystyle \frac{1}{2} = \frac{y}{2-x_{i}^{*}}$

Isolating yields that

$\displaystyle y = 1 - \frac{x_{i}^{*}}{2}$

Now we use hint 3 and write down the necessary formulas. For volume of
the \emph{i}th piece, we have

$V_{i} = y\Delta x \cdot 10 = 10( 1 - \frac{x_{i}^{*}}{2})\Delta x = (10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x$

For the mass of the \emph{i}th piece, where $density = \rho =1000$, we
have

$m_{i} = V\cdot \rho = (10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x (1000) = 1000(10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x$

For the force, where $g = 9.8$, we have

$F_{i} = m_{i}a = 9.8(1000(10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x) = 9800(10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x$

For the work on the \emph{i}th piece, we have

$W_{i} = F_{i} \cdot d =  9800(10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x(x_{i}^{*}) = 9800x_{i}^{*}(10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x$

and so the total work done is

$W = \lim_{n \to \infty}\sum_{i=1}^{n}W_{i} = \int_{0}^{2}9800x(10-5x)\,dx$

completing the question.

sols_raw:
A picture is included at the bottom of the page. Let <math> x_{i}^{*} </math> be a sample point.

First, we use similar triangles as in the diagram to see that

<math> \displaystyle
\frac{1}{2} = \frac{y}{2-x_{i}^{*}}
</math>

Isolating yields that

<math> \displaystyle
y = 1 - \frac{x_{i}^{*}}{2}
</math>

Now we use hint 3 and write down the necessary formulas. For volume of the ''i''th piece, we have

<math>
V_{i} = y\Delta x \cdot 10 = 10( 1 - \frac{x_{i}^{*}}{2})\Delta x = (10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x
</math>

For the mass of the ''i''th piece, where <math> density = \rho =1000</math>, we have

<math>
m_{i} = V\cdot \rho = (10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x (1000) = 1000(10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x
</math>

For the force, where <math> g = 9.8 </math>, we have

<math>
F_{i} = m_{i}a = 9.8(1000(10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x) = 9800(10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x
</math>

For the work on the ''i''th piece, we have

<math>
W_{i} = F_{i} \cdot d =  9800(10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x(x_{i}^{*}) = 9800x_{i}^{*}(10 - 5x_{i}^{*})\Delta x
</math>

and so the total work done is

<math>
W = \lim_{n \to \infty}\sum_{i=1}^{n}W_{i} = \int_{0}^{2}9800x(10-5x)\,dx
</math>

completing the question.

[[File:MATH101Apr2009Q7b.jpeg]]
statement_html:
An open metal tank has two ends which are isosceles triangles with vertex at the bottom, two sides which are rectangular, and an open top. The tank is 1 metre wide, 2 metres deep, 10 metres long and full of water (density = 1000 kg/m3).

(b) Express the work required to pump the water out of the tank, if it is pumped out over the top edge, as an integral (Do not evaluate the integral.)
statement_latex:
An open metal tank has two ends which are isosceles triangles with
vertex at the bottom, two sides which are rectangular, and an open top.
The tank is 1 metre wide, 2 metres deep, 10 metres long and full of
water (\emph{density = 1000 kg/m\textsuperscript{3}}).

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
(b) Express the work required to pump the water out of the tank, if it
is pumped out over the top edge, as an integral (\emph{Do not evaluate
the integral.})
\end{description}
statement_raw:
An open metal tank has two ends which are isosceles triangles with vertex at the bottom, two sides which are rectangular, and an open top. The tank is 1 metre wide, 2 metres deep, 10 metres long and full of water (''density = 1000 kg/m<sup>3</sup>'').

:(b) Express the work required to pump the water out of the tank, if it is pumped out over the top edge, as an integral (''Do not evaluate the integral.'')
